Award.AwardTitle: Iterative Experimental-Computational Design of Hydrogel Systems for Biomedical Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports fundamental research on methods for the design of engineered biomaterials. Historically, engineering of biomaterials has focused on biological effects but often ignored the advanced material fabrication and characterization needed to realize the desired biomechanical behavior. This research considers anisotropic and layered hydrogels for tissue engineering applications. The outcome of the research would be a methodology for the design these biomaterials. It integrates manufacturing and biomechanical characterization with the goal to arrive at biomaterials that correspond to complex tissues in the human body. Three target tissues are considered: trachea, intervertebral disks and heart valves. The research outcomes would greatly improve and accelerate the engineering process and thereby make engineered biomaterials more readily available. The outcomes of the research endeavor will also be integrated into educational initiatives through direct involvement of students in research, the development of new educational materials, and mentoring of undergraduate senior design teams.

This project's approach is an iterative design methodology for anisotropic and layered hydrogel systems with regional dependent properties. It integrates manufacturing processes, experimental and computational characterization of the microstructured hydrogel systems to arrive at biomaterials that mimic connective tissues. Tissues with fibrous reinforcements (trachea), with layered structure (intervertebral disks), and tissue both patterned and layered (heart valves) are considered. The combined in silico-in vitro design process relies on fundamental advances at the interface between manufacturing, experimental and computational mechanics of soft materials, as well as mathematics. The iterative design starts with the preparation of samples of patterned or layered hydrogels, which will follow the topology of the specific tissue. Molecular weights for layers and for fiber patterns will be chosen such that the global stiffness approximates that of the real tissue in its most common state (e.g., compression for intervertebral disk). Photolithography and staged crosslinking will be used to manufacture materials. Samples will be tested in tension, compression, and bending. Computational models for the biomechanical response will be established which integrate the experimental data through constitutive formulations. Coarse level numerical optimization is performed in a reduced parameter space to approach the target behavior in all possible stress and deformation states encountered by the specific tissues. Further fabrication and experiments on hydrogel systems with more complex heterogeneity are then enabled based on the initial results. Hydrogel systems mimicking the tissue of interest would emerge from exercising the approach in the full parameter space such that optimal topologies and composition are achieved.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The fabrication of biologically mimetic materials is of great interest to the field of tissue-engineering, which aims to reduce the harmful impact of diseased or damaged connective tissues in the human body through the design of suitable prosthetic tissue. Hydrogels prepared from a crosslinkable synthetic polymer, polyethylene glycol diacrylate (PEGDA), are a popular material candidate for this application owing to their ability to replicate desirable biological features of native tissues from the human body. However, their mechanical properties are drastically different from such tissue. This mismatch strongly limits their ability to act as a tissue substitute, especially for mechanically active tissues such as heart valves. The research supported by this grant aimed to prepare hydrogels with a greater degree of sophistication in their mechanical properties, namely by mimicking the anisotropic and nonlinear mechanical behavior found in biological tissues. Our approach involved the use of photolithography to fabricate hydrogels with patterned stiffness, with highly crosslinked, stiffer hydrogel varieties playing the part of reinforcements within minimally crosslinked, weaker hydrogel varieties.  However, determining the patterns required for the composite hydrogel to demonstrate desirable mechanical properties purely by experimentation would be a time-consuming and material intensive process. We generated a computational framework using Finite Element Analysis (FEA) validated by experimental data to investigate the impact of hydrogel stiffness pattern geometries on the mechanical properties of the composite. This framework allowed us to predictively determine the patterns that resulted in the composite hydrogels displaying anisotropic and nonlinear mechanical behavior. In order to fabricate these constructs, a low-cost laser-based collimated illumination system was constructed to generate hydrogels with these patterns. These hydrogels were then embedded into a weaker base matrix using a novel two-step illumination process to finalize the crosslinking and composite gels formation. Mechanical testing of the combined material indicated excellent agreement between predicted and experimental stress-strain curves for the selected reinforcement geometries.  Ultimately, this project resulted in a robust computational to experimental pipeline for the fabrication of stiffness-composite hydrogels, and additionally resulted in hydrogels with biologically salient mechanical properties.

Broader Impacts: The research supported by this grant has resulted in the publication of four peer-reviewed manuscripts. It has also informed the development of ongoing research projects, including using the patterns obtained herein to fabricate hydrogel-carbon nanotube (CNT) composites, and to guide the design of 3D-printed materials to fabricate heart valve models with patient-specific geometries. The project was also integral to the training of five graduate students, who learned valuable lab skills. The work performed herein necessitated a high degree of collaboration between the PIs and the students involved, which provided the students with invaluable training with regards to interdisciplinary science and communication skills. Additionally, two undergraduate students and one high school student were also involved in the work, which allowed for further dissemination of these skills while also providing the graduate students with leadership and communication skills for working with students of various socio-economic and scientific backgrounds. The PIs and graduate students involved in this project were also active in disseminating the computational and experimental knowledge gained from this project to the broader scientific community via presentations at several national and international conferences and in seminar presentations.


Last Modified: 08/29/2019
Modified by: Ilinca Stanciulescu
